Its a movie that show us the love of a son to his dad. This film has something for everyone. At times it makes you love and it makes you cry also. Thats why this film is Must See for all movie lovers and escapable for those who are admirers of Tom Hanks. Great Movie . I loved this movie

I'm Actually Surprised This Movie Isn't On The Top 250, this movie has every possible element to make a good movie, the kind warmhearted hero, Viktor Navorski, His Honest Love Interest, Amelia, The Evil Villain, Frank Dixon and the loyal friends, Gupta and Enrique and others... It's Not Just the amazing Powerful Performance of tom hanks that draws your attention, it's also the high values that this movie suggests, like the worth of friendship,(Spoiler) that shows best in the scene where Gupta Stands in front of an airplane holding his mob and then yells "I'm going home",also the beauty of love,(Spoiler)where Amelia tells Viktor About Napoleon and Josephine in the last scene where they meet, and last but not the least the value of a promise,(Spoiler) which I think it best shows where Viktor tells Amelia " I think my father would do it for me", you just feel how great this character is...In The End, it's just a lovely movie about waiting, and how it can change your entire life.

What do you image of "Terminal"?It is very busy space where many people arrive and go out in days. Many people are glad to see their friends again, many people say good-bye to their close people. John F. Kennedy International Airport is the one of the airport where we can see the dramatical movie.Viktor Navorski, a man from the of Krakozhia arrives at the airport and go to the gate to the entrance of America. But when he shows a past port, suddenly the officer let him to the room and says "You cannot enter to here." As his homeland's government lose their political power and the country has breakdown. Viktor cannot go back to Krakozhia but also he cannot enter America. He forces to stay this airport until the war calms down. He starts to stay all day (including night) in the airport which is very close to America, but very remote place at the same time. Few months later, the news inform that the war of Krakozhia is over. He expects to enter America, but he is not allowed. He can go back to his homeland, but he is not intend to do. He is saying "I have a promise why I am staying here." What is the promise? To keep his promise, he tries to enter America...This movie is a heart-warming movie. Viktor Navorski has hardship and his desire is dying. However he has very strong spirit and power to change the things to the better way. He makes friends and learning delight from this situation. And also this movie is romantic comedy! He falls in love with the woman who works as a flight attendant. Everything starts with despair, but he lives well at there. I can infer that he has a talent to adapt to any situation which occurs. His homeland, Krakozhia is not unreal country in this world but it is not an unrealistic movie I feel. It shows a touching movie to everyone. I like this movie very much.

Tom Hanks shines in this heartwarming, eye-opening film about the man who has fallen into the only crack in the U.S. customs department. Unable to return to a war-stricken Krakozhia and unable to enter the U.S. he is stuck in a never-ending no-man's land; a place where he doesn't feel welcome, doesn't feel wanted, and does not belong. A place he calls home, but we call the Terminal. This 2004 film, directed by Stephen Spielberg, stars Tom Hanks in the lead role as a Krakozhian immigrant grounded to the JFK airport, who has to learn to adapt to American culture without stepping foot on its soil. Tom Hanks accurately portrays a non-American traveler, and successfully places himself in the shoes of a lost immigrant. His lovable persona and barely understandable accent captivates the audience and has them willing to follow him to Krakozhia and back by the end of the film. His character befriends a motley crew of janitorial workers, and even catches the eye of a flight attendant played by Catherine Zeta-Jones. Together with his newfound friends, he discovers what it truly means to be an American and realizes that the home he had been searching for was just through the doors of gate 67. Viktor Navorski, played by Tom Hanks, isn't your average traveler. He can't speak, can't read, and can hardly navigate his way around a crowded airport food court. He shaves in the restrooms, parades around in a bathrobe, and feasts on saltine crackers doused in condiments. He is alone in a foreign country, hated by authority, and not trusted by the staff. The majority is indifferent towards him, ignoring his cries of anguish over confusion from the news, and not stopping to help him use the phone despite his pleas. He is unwanted, unwelcome, and unacceptable, but he is also ambitious. And through that ambition he finds friendship, happiness, and a little love on the side. Expert film critics Ryan "the Rain Maker" Rodela, and Justin "Horse-whispering" Holland each gave the movie two thumbs up along with a 4.5 star rating out of a possible 5. So whether you're waiting for a flight, or just sitting at home with nothing to do, the Terminal promises to take off, entertain, and land you with the perfect family film.

Review title: Living a life based on true values
Review_body: There is no other movie I did watch for as many times as this one. And this is because even today I find myself absorbed by the simplicity of the story, the limited but lively space set and the authenticity of the main character. For me it is one of the best examples of what it means to live a life guided and inspired by values; values that you respect and never abandon. In the same time is one of those movies that comes so close to being a theater play. A play that makes you forget about anything else and just live next to the characters, feel their lives, worries and joys. I simply love it. And, Thank You Tom Hanks for playing this part so well. I am sure I will get to watch it again soon.

I simply loved this movie and that's why iam writing this review.The plot is pretty simple, movie has all the human emotions that exist in life, although the country is fictional still the situation is valid and i must say I'd related this situation with myself.Person not knowing the local language, not having money, not having any friend or family is simply "Unacceptable" but the way Viktor Novarski managed was simply amazing to me.The beauty of this film lies in the emotions which all the characters of this movie displayed like Gupta the skeptic, Enrique the lover boy, Frank Dixon the new boss. Every person of this movie matches the persons of real life and how they behave is been portrayed beautifully in this movie.In short it's a feel good movie where in the start you can have any emotions but in the end you'll always come up with a smile.

Tom Hanks is both funny and endearing in his role as a stranded foreigner. He pulls the accent off nicely, and is able to make us believe something that quite frankly seemed too far fetched before actually seeing the film. The Indian janitor steals the show with his performance - he has short, cutting jokes and an amazing gift for plate spinning. The evil character in the movie is very detestable, which makes everything work. Spielberg has come up with another great movie. There were numerous laugh-out-loud moments where the entire audience was cheering, and you are left genuinely rooting for Hanks' character. I would recommend this film to anyone looking for a fun two hours of entertainment.

Review title: I think I was in the theater for weeks
Review_body: This was easily the most boring movie I have ever had to sit through. It seemed to go on and on. I went to a noon show, and was genuinely shocked to see that it was still light outside when I left the theater. The only excuse I can possible imagine is the the director wanted the audience to know how the guy in theairport must have felt waiting around forever. I went to see it with my mother for her birthday, she is a huge Tom Hanks fan and adores sappy love stories, buteven she said she was bored out of her mind. Do not go see or rent this movie unless you are mad at your significant other and want to punish them!Sorry Tom, but this was a lousy movie!

This is a film that more than challenged my ability to suspend disbelief while enjoying a light summer evening's entertainment. Watching Stanley Tucci, as Security Chief of a major American airport, persist in explaining rather complicated immigration problems to Tom Hanks, a would-be immigrant who spoke absolutely NO English, was really too much. And that was just the beginning.If I had not seen the credits you could not have persuaded me that Steven Spielberg was responsible for this. As for Tom Hanks, I prefer to believe he was only following orders.

There is no such country as Krakhozia, Tom Hanks is playing Bulgarian in this movie, that's the country what he is actually talking about, he is talking to Bulgarian, and his passport is Bulgarian too (BULGARIA was never named Krakhozia, and never will be(I don't know why the director's of this movie decided to name it like that)), his passport is RED and a few country's in the world have RED passport's. Anyway about the movie, I think American's need to think about their immigration system, and how they treat people like the person in the movie. The movie is 10 out of 10, it has a great compelling scenarios and the actor's play is awesome, and this movie stick's in your head for a long long time, so that's the three thing's what you need for a good movie. For all the people what haven't watched this movie, I'm so jealous I wanna watch it again!!!

I saw this movie only recently.may be its too late.but anyways it was awesome.Being inspired by a true story ,the plot was original and did justice to the same.First ,I have to congratulate TOM HANKS as he did a great job in this movie.His acting was mind blowing.Next is STEVEN Spielberg.I know him making unusual movies like JURASSIC PARK,MIB etc.But this time he rocks big time.He proved himself to be a great director of all time with any kind of plot.I really appreciate him a lot for making this kind of movie.Technically,everything is classy in this movie.Overall a great performance from the entire cast.Hats off!!!!

I am so glad there are movies out there for grown ups! This movie made me feel like I could like going to the movies and paying the full price for them instead of going to the matinée or waiting for a video rental. Review_body: well normally i don't write reviews , actually ,that's my first review of any movie. i am compelled to write this review because i think this a kind of movie which shows you how a genius director with the help of a genius actor could make a masterpiece out of a simple, normal storyline. my eyes were filled with tears when our own protagonist steps out of THE TERMINAL.i was not only crying but was overjoyed by this accomplishment of Mr. victor navorsky . i was more than content after watching this movie and could recommend anyone to share the pathos of victor(hanks).Spielberg and hanks, both had given their best and honest efforts in the movie and endowed us audience with a audio-visual delight.what is painful to me is that this movie is somewhat underrated when it comes in comparison to other movies of hanks or Spielberg.i mean at least this movie deserve an 8+ rating on IMDb. good luck navorsky.

A must watch movie.
I am big fan of Tom Hanks and this is really good movie.

Review title: Spielberg, Hanks & Williams should have done better
Review_body: When a project involves such giants as Spielberg and Hanks one would expect the best caliber from these two capable artists. What they've created instead is very average in many respects. The plot is forced and clumsy and the story doesn't wrap up in a satisfying way. This could have been a typical "comedy of errors" formula or a volley of wit vs. wit between Hanks' character and Stanley Tucci's. But there's only a hint of these traits. There's nothing inventive about the production, storytelling, or directing. Spielberg throws in the towel on this one. I don't believe Hanks as a doe-eyed lovable non-English-speaking punching bag who knows only enough English to be slightly funny. He's more creepy then lovable. There's nothing convincing in any of the relationships neither between Hanks and Catherine Zeta-Jones nor any secondary characters. The movie is more frustrating then anything. I don't believe that any normal human being caught in those situations would remain so meek for so long. And if anyone does then they deserve what they get. For me one of the biggest disappointment in this movie is John William's contribution. His decision to go small scale was good, but the music he wrote for this has no personality. If the creative team here were any other people I'd give this a 6 out of 10. But considering the quality of creators I give this a 4 out of 10.

Review title: 1 of the WORST movies I have ever seen
Review_body: To say this film is 'loosely' based on fact is an over statement! This film is so unbelievable, I had to watch it the whole way through because I could not believe such big names (Spielberg, Hanks, Zeta Jones), would have touched this one with a ten foot barge pole. After about 3 minutes of watching my jaw dropped wide open and stayed like that till the end, except for the 2 worst moments namely: 1. That stupid dinner on the 'patio' with bungling waiters and the juggler - what the hell was that all about 2. When Hanks made the Napoleon mosaic fountain thing out of a mens urinal (talk about taking the P).Do not waste your time with this movie!!!! This rates right up there with Cliffhanger (Stallone) as one of the worst films ever made...

I was amazed at how well Tom Hanks maintained an Eastern European persona throughout the movie. How others and Victor played off each other was enjoyable to watch. However, the role played by Catherine Zeta Jones was not exceptional. For her to be in love with a married man when she can easily meet many others during her travels doesn't make sense. If the writers put more thought into her role, she would have had a great character to contrast Victors. As for Tom, some would argue that his Victor shows too much ingenuity while coping with being stuck in the airport terminal, but ask yourself, he somehow manages to go NYC from his Eastern European country and he is a skilled carpenter. I would say he didn't play Victor... he was Victor.

The Terminal was an enjoyable film. It made me laugh and cry. It is not always necessary to "reach to the core of humanity" for a film to be enjoyable. Sometimes "a cigar is just a cigar". Sometimes a film is meant to entertain, and if we can find deeper meaning attached,so much the better.Do you suppose it was as simple as watching a polite man caught in an uncomfortable situation and seeing how he dealt with it? Manners are underused in this world. It was a touching film, and I and my spouse both enjoyed it. The actors did as they should do, they transformed themselves into the characters they portrayed. After a few minutes, it wasn't Hanks but Viktor that I was traveling with through his trials. And do you know, through it all, Viktor displayed the finest qualities of man....gentleness, manners, concern for others. Bravo, the film was lovely.

I enjoyed the movie very much. It was very funny, and the whole movie theater was filled with laughter. It also has some sweet moments as well as a few sad ones, which evens it out.Hanks did a very good job in his role with great acting, and Zeta-Jones made her character more realistic than many other actresses could. All of the smaller characters were also played very well especially the airport cleaner.A movie that is good for any age and a wide variety of different people. A very enjoyable show overall, probably one of my favorite shows so far this year. I recommend it for everyone.

I thought that The Terminal was a great film. I wasn't expecting it to be comical too. It was genuinely funny in some parts; the audience (myself included) erupted into laughter countless times.I also loved the relationships between the characters. Hanks should definitely be nominated for an Oscar. His accent in the movie and portrayal of the character was amazing. He was like a completely different person. Stanley Tucci was also great. His character wasn't exactly my favorite, but he played the part well. You might expect the movie to be boring because it takes place in one setting, but it is the exact opposite. We gain insight into this completely different world. Stephen Spielberg did a great job once again. Hanks and Spielberg make quite a team. If you want to see a genuinely good film that will make you laugh and entertain you, I highly suggest seeing this film.

Review title: Hard to go wrong with Hanks and Spielberg!
Review_body: "Terminal" starts off a little slow but picks up steam as Hank's character (Viktor) develops.I enjoyed watching Viktor as a traveler from a distant country grow as he learned the language and interacted with the employees of the airport. There is something admirable about the way he sees life. He isn't corrupted by America's insatiable greed.There were however a couple inconsistencies that made no sense. First, when Viktor helps the hispanic fellow meet the customs officer there needs to be a scene initiating a courtship prior to the marriage proposal. Second, the way Victor's flight was delayed at the end of the movie seemed unrealistic.I highly recommend "The Terminal". It's one of those movies that just makes you feel good and doesn't compromise your senses. Very little profanity (a few "S" words), no sex and no violence. Just maybe Hollywood is figuring out that you don't have to shock people to make a good movie.

Steven Spielberg and Tom Hanks have done it again. These two individually can almost completely ensure the success of a movie, and together, they are simply spectacular. This movie is touching and funny in all the right places. It is a tribute to the craftsmanship involved in making this movie that Catherine Zeta-Jones has to take backseat, but her acting was delicately understated. There is no question that Tom Hanks is a fine actor, but he creates this character in such a believable way that the audience easily forgets that he is Tom Hanks, a face we all can recognize, and begins to see him as a foreign man. He gives us an intelligent and compassionate character that we can immediately sympathize with.In such a character-driven movie, the protagonist is almost as important as the antagonist, and Stanley Tucci in the role of Frank Dixon hardly slouches there. Though his motivation is clear from the beginning and he never strays from a normal human character, I found myself whispering curses at the screen whenever he showed up to make Victor's (Tom Hanks) life just a little more difficult. There are sweet moments, such as when the hard-nosed INS officer and the man who runs the food truck use Victor as a go-between in a blind love affair. There are heart-wrenching moments, like the very beginning when Victor sees news coverage all in English that tells of the war in his country and struggles to understand. All in all, a movie I would recommend to almost anyone able to see it.

Review title: Creatively done movie, with humor and a touch of humanity
Review_body: 'The Terminal' is a creative movie, providing the viewer with laughter, hope and a sense of humanity that is in all of us. With all the harsh, crass and fatalistic movies coming out of Hollywood these days this movie was light, uplifting and really funny. While it was not truly idealistic, it was based on true events that happened to someone at another time, in another country and in another airport. But really, unless movies are based on true human events or history, many of our movies are quite fictitious and leave a lot to be desired with regard to the story's plot and objective. In fact, Hollywood has been definitely gravitating towards the mighty, powerful special effects story lines and has loss the touch of human individuality the how people can reach out and connect with one another. A movie does not need to be totally realistic in order to convey this and 'The Terminal' does an excellent job of uplifting the heart and giving us pause to laugh and have hope.As usual Tom Hanks does an outstanding job, taking on a role that is challenging and then mastering it. Some reviews have considered the movie without any redemptive qualities and not worth watching. Unfortunately, this is totally wrong and I trust that movie goers will see this is a film well worth watching.

Review title: Really Good Film! Funny and Entertaining!
Review_body: I saw The Terminal On opening Night and i really enjoyed it.Tom Hanks is a great actor overall and proves this to be true in this Film. Speaking with the accent he did, must of been difficult but Hanks pulled it off with great success. I personally had no dislikes about the film and believe that Tom Hanks has yet again stretched the limits for a great film.Overall i would recommend everyone to see this film, it is a great film and for sure will be added to my collection when released on DVD.

Review title: Exhibits the heart and spirit of a smart independent film.
Review_body: SPOILER***********SPOILER**************SPOILERTerminal is the story of a son's pledge to his father. Victor Navorski [Tom Hanks] deplanes at Kennedy Airport from his Eastern European home of Krakozia with a suitcase and a Planters Peanut can. He finds that---while in transit---his government has been overthrown and his passport is invalid.Officer Frank Dixon [Stanley Tucci] explains to Victor that he's only temporarily trapped in US Immigration hell. Frank gives Victor a fist full of food vouchers, a pager so he can be reached, and turns him loose in the airport 'transit lounge', a giant shopping center with a food court. A man without a country, Victor speaks no English, has no money or friends, and doesn't understand the 'system'; but he's far from stupid. Hours pass into days and weeks, and Victor sets up housekeeping at Gate 67, an unused part of the terminal under renovation. He sets about learning English, gets a job and creates a support group---always keeping an eye on the Planters Peanut can. Victor befriends an emotionally vulnerable stewardess [Catherine Zeta-Jones] and an airport romance blooms. Can Victor outlast the system, see the Big Apple and make his Dad's dream come true?Terminal is innovative, engaging, entertaining and has a highly unlikely storyline for a mass marketed film. This movie---playing to large audiences---is a joy to watch and exhibits the heart and spirit of a smart independent film dressed in Hollywood clothing. I say this even after being put on notice by a friend regarding minor technical inconsistencies. These can be overlooked if you're willing to believe an immigrant can live in Kennedy Airport. Two features make this movie sparkle and a joy to watch. First is Victor Navorski, a guy you've just got to love, who exhibits the immigrant motivation, ingenuity and desire that make our country great. Second is the supporting cast. Immigration Officer Dixon [Tucci] is a work-a-day guy just trying to stay out of trouble long enough to inherit his boss' job; he sees Victor as a threat. Zeta-Jones [as Amelia] constrains her star power and instead creates a superb cameo role as a stewardess with a cover girl persona and shattered romantic relationships; Victor is a soft shoulder. Kumar Pallanatucci [Gupta the lounge janitor] is a paranoid immigrant who sees CIA agents in the shadows and only talks to strangers after they make an appointment. Chi McBride [from TV's Boston Public] is a baggage handler who knows how to enjoy his work. Terminal is another Tom Hanks and Steven Spielberg collaboration and looks to be as good as their earlier efforts; remember Catch Me If You Can [2002] and Saving Private Ryan [1998]. The story is cleverly cast as a comedy, not as a tragedy; and, the supporting characters are incredibly real and enduring. The film runs just a little over two hours, more than enough time for the plot to evolve.

*Spoilers*Okay I had to write an essay on this film and here it is:The Terminal: a film with a compelling title, a compelling story, and a compelling cast. In my preview journal, I have set high anticipations for the film and my movie-going experience. But is the movie truly worth the hype? The Terminal, although a decent feel-good comedy/drama, suffers because of script and acting errors, coupled with a loss of focus and a ludicrous finish. The Terminal is a recent comedy/drama directed by Steven Spielberg. The film stars Tom Hanks as Viktor Navorski, and Catherine Zeta-Jones as Amelia.To abridge the plot, Viktor Navorski arrives in New York from the fictitious republic of Krakozhia, only to be detained from entering the States because of a political coup inside of his country. Navorski cannot enter New York, and neither can he go back. He is forced to stay at the airport's international terminal. During his 9-month stay at the terminal, Viktor learns English,makes friends, falls in love, and makes trouble for Frank Dixon, the airport' s evil security and immigration officer (played by Stanley Lucci). The film is 2:09 in duration, has many sub-plots and frequently goes off on a tangent. In basis, the movie attempts to convey a foreigner's unfamiliarity and him accustoming with a new life.The Terminal in spirit is a heart-warming feel-good drama. Despite frequent clichés and tacky romance, the film establishes this spirit for three fourths of its duration. However, the plot suffers from many obvious holes and mistakes. At the time Viktor Navorski arrives at the airport (which is a vast multi-million dollar set erected exclusively for this cinema) and is denied clearance, he is allowed to reside within the terminal complex. As message boards point out, by law he would have to be detained in a prison (which would not make for a very good story).The movie theatre itself and my fellow viewers were a practical microcosm to help me build my opinions of The Terminal. The audience seemed to notice when something in the film was in disarray, and laughed at the humorous moments. Indeed, many parts in this film were comical, helping to provide a light aura to the plot. The acting of this picture is decent, though Hanks plays much too enthusiastically. He obtains the role of an Eastern European man and twists him into a juvenile buffoon. Hanks' voicing in particularly outlandish: he tries for a thick, Slavic accent, but ends up speaking in Bulgarian for the entirety of the film. One side-plot is particularly comical: a Russian traveler purchases medicine in America in order to cure his father back home, then is asked to withhold these medicines. The Russian threatens to commit suicide, and Navorski is brought in as a translator. The evil terminal czar Frank announces that '[The Russian] lives across from Krakozhia's border, and may converse in a different dialect.' As anticipated, the Russian man and Viktor comprehend each other beautifully. After an explanation that these pills are for a goat, the Russian man is set free to take a plane back home. As a show of Hollywood ignorance and simplicity, this could be deemed the worst episode in the film, and one may suppose it could have been a lot more elementary for Hanks to speak in Russian. If The Terminal tells an intriguing story leading up the climax, then the story's conclusion spells death for a potentially high-quality production. Many plot-loops are amiss in the film's conclusion. Viktor's love interest Amelia Warren regresses yet again to her boyfriend, murdering half the plot and tarnishing a happy ending. The Indian airport janitor Gupta (played by Kumar Pallana) makes an unexplained sacrifice for Navorski. Gupta delays Navorski's plane back to Krakozhia by running out onto the tarmac and stopping the arriving airplane with his mop. Gupta is then held at gunpoint by a SWAT team, and taken back to India, where he will wither away in jail for seven years, as a result of attacking a policeman years ago. The story, naturally, does not make any note of this. All too late in the movie, the audience learns Viktor's absurd motive for coming to America in the first place: to receive a signature from a jazz player (who has evidently played at the same hotel in New York for 9 months). The conclusion of The Terminal breaks apart desperately. Overall, I had much higher standards and expectations about this movie, due to its cast and the director's reputation. I am not necessarily in favor of films that portray reality unerringly, however the plot holes were both significant and palpable in The Terminal. Meanwhile I enjoyed the film, better execution and a more realistic script would have cured the movie of its blemishes.

My wife and I feel that this is a marvelous film with the potential to become a classic. Tom Hanks is, as always, superb with an outstanding supporting cast. He is certainly the premier cinema actor of these times. The script portrayed every type of character that we could possibly encounter in any situation dealing with bureaucracy. Besides the person Hanks played there are all of the prototypes which we seem to envision in our daily lives. My favorite was the chief of US Immigration at JFK. We have all encountered someone like him more than once. It a great story which was beautifully filmed, wonderfully produced and overall a winner. I would recommend 'The Terminal' to anyone. Good clean fun with plenty of laughs thrown in as a bonus.

Review title: SPOILER some spoilage, Listen to Roshnir
Review_body: It is great to be company with two other perceptive viewers of movies, roshnir and i-love- tom-hanks. I also agree that there is a political statement being made about the red tape in the U.S. and Homeland paranoia. One can see with the scene where a fellow Eastern European was caught bringing in prescriptions to the U.S. for his father. He was bringing it from Canada and the scene is about the exorbitant and ridiculous cost of prescription meds, here in the U.S. and the satire of the pharmaceutical companies and the role of the government and restrictions imposed upon the consumer in dire need of the meds. Here, he is let go if it is for his goat, then it is admissible. All these rules and regulations which dictates the U.S. law and government comes into play. Furthermore, in the beginning of the movie, Commissioner Dixon tries to figure out all these regulations and codes to bypass his problem and to get Viktor (Tom Hanks) out of his hair, bald though he is, not to criticize Tucci. Another tidbit is in the very beginning of the movie. It is ironic that the we are asked by passing through security we are always asked, "Are you here for business or pleasure." There are a couple of shots showing this ridiculous question. We are like in a processing line, like robots giving our standard cookie cutter response from a cookie cutter question. I always think about the California cheese TV commercial. The security person asks us, "What is your reason for visiting California?" Everyone is different but they all say "the cheese." When this unfortunate fellow says something else rather than cheese, he is whisked away. Funny but that says something about our government. To get to the point, I thoroughly enjoyed the movie. And come on, do we always have to have the cookie cutter ending where the guy always gets the gal. What made Casablanca great? As roshnir says:"subtlety" of this movie is very skillfully done and I'm glad Spielberg took on this film and know why. It is not a stretch for the imagination, such contrivances are based on a true incident Gazzo2! For the story to be believable, it would take 9 months to birth the relationships that Viktor (Tom Hanks) has with all the employees at JFK. And the little Indian guys does stop an airplane not just spinning plates. Amelia (Catherine Zeta-Jones) falls for Viktor on meeting him in happenstance initially and other occasions that builds up to their relationship which does take TIME. It is conceivable that a country would take months to get its affairs in order. If you look a little deeper you would be engaging your mind rather than going on autopilot. The tagline is: "Life is waiting." If you took the time to look between the lines, you probably would have got a better perspective of the movie. The cuteness of the Tom Hanks is played to a tee and he fit this role perfectly. This is not meant to be an action packed movie. Maybe that is why the zzzzzzz's. Look for a pleasant surprise about life and its twists and turns. Take the TIME to see this movie.

This film, with no exception is the worse film I have ever seen (And I've seen a lot) from start to finish it was sugar coated, I felt no compassion at all for Tom Hank's character and couldn't wait for the end. To spend the whole film in the Terminal added to the boredom of the film, perhaps it could have had flash backs or something, Anything!!!!!Katherine Zita Jones, (In fairness) wasn't as bad as she usually is, but that could have been because the film itself was so bad made her look OK! Tom Hanks, whilst acting his socks off, as he usually does, really didn't come good this time, and I'd recommend giving this stupid film, a wide birth!

A light presentation of one-man struggle with bureaucracy and prejudice against foreigners. Sadly, Viktor Navorski, a man, who planned only a short term visit in New York city, is stuck at the airport, because of unfortunate events in his country and the American officials' inability to deal with this unexpected situation. The story shows how one man, against all odds, manages to provide for himself and his needs using only his own wits. Although not popular with the officials, he's friendly character earns him friends among other ordinary people. Although set in the US this drama could have take place anywhere in the world, where foreigners (especially eastern-Europeans) are still considered second-class citizens.

The Terminal is an unlikely story of a traveler who is stranded in New York's JFK airport because his country's (a fictitious Eastern European nation) government has just been overthrown, and the immigration officials refuse to admit or deport him. He is stuck in the transit lounge, and must survive as best he can.The story has a familiar ring to it: the protagonist is stranded by unfortunate circumstances, but by his ingenuity, he survives and even prospers in the face of opposition. What's new is the setting - how Spielberg turns the modern international transit lounge (a comfortable place nowadays - shops, restaurants, amenities) into a cold forbidding place populated with strangers.Tom Hanks plays the role of a foreign visitor who has to rely on his wits at first, but in the end he prospers because his honest nature has won the trust and friendship of the airport workers. He even catches the eye of an air stewardess (Catherine Zeta-Jones, who is simply luminous!) while struggling with the bureaucrats running the airport who conspire to deny him his chance to get out.The film does require that the viewer suspends his sense of reality for a while - in one scene, Hank's character gets a job as a building worker in the airport after a painting a wall in a single night with such skill that he impresses the foreman. And he learns a new language by comparing the foreign language version of Fodor's travel guide to the English version.Happily, I must say that these imperfections do not detract from the spirit of the movie, and can heartily commend it to those who are looking for a well-scripted story with an excellent cast. Seven stars.

Review title: Comical yet unclear at times, never the less great.
Review_body: In The Terminal, Viktor Navorski (Tom Hanks) arrives at JFK International Airport only to find out that during the flight from his homeland, a coup over threw the current government spinning the country of Krakhosia into an indefinite war. Upon landing in the Big Apple, the limited English speaking Navorski is shuffled through the intimidating customs network only to be denied entry to the United States; which does not recognize Krakhosian passports in lieu of the political upheaval taking place. Unable to enter America and unable to go back home, Tom Hanks portrays a man stuck in the airport with no country to wait for something to happen in The Terminal. Considering the tight constraints on setting, director Steven Spielberg holds onlookers in their seats waiting for the next laugh in a comedy which at times has an unclear direction on where the plot is going.Tom Hanks pulls off a convincing accent while playing the innocent immigrant who only has one purpose of being in America which has to do with the peanut can he carries with him. This purpose is discovered by a love interest and flight attendant, Amelia Warren (Catherine Zeta-Jones), who otherwise plays a seemingly unnecessary role which ends without closure. Other supporting roles include a group of airport employees, whom one of them finds enjoyment at watching travelers fall on the newly washed concourse floor. Tom Hanks is without a doubt the spearhead of the movie as he pulls off yet another great act while the less familiar supporting actors contribute to the overall success of the film.The actors were well directed in the roles which they were portraying. Spielberg does a great job of molding what would seem to be a limited script into a movie worth seeing. Who would have thought that a movie taking place solely within an airport could have been as creatively made? However, it cannot be ignored that at times there seemed to be some jumps made throughout the plot.The majority of the plot consists of the comical interactions of Navorski and the airport employees. At first the employees are skeptical of Navorski however they come to build a strong relationship with the man who lives at Gate 67 after he helps save a fellow immigrant from the grasps of the head of airport security. In addition, there appears to be another storyline between Navorski and Warren which makes it unclear as to which storyline is most important and how they fit together. These dueling story lines at times leaves the viewer confused as to the significance of what just played out in front of them.Despite the awkward cohesion of story lines, Spielberg saves the at times seemingly terminal film through his direction. The Terminal manages to bring the audience into the concourses of JFK International Airport and provide them with good humor and a heartfelt story through the comical acting of a great cast.

Review title: How far would you go for a................Promise!!!
Review_body: I was very disappointed with Steven Spielberg, the way he has managed to present it and even with very high star cast the all over movie was simply nothing.The concept of keeping a long kept promise for the father was good but seemed very unrealistic. The actions and the story line which followed in the movie wasn't that compelling. The series of incidents seemed very artificial.Tom Hanks came out as a shiner with his amazing performance like always but I never felt involved in the movie like it should happen. They could have done more with the great cast. In the Nutshell, it was a movie for the sake of making a movie.I would not recommend it if you are looking for any excitement.

I thought that this was a truly brilliant movie...a little eccentric, but brilliant at that. It was a fairly simple plot, but at the same time...very "in depth" if you get my drift. Oh yea, and Tom Hanks rocks the Krackovian (or w/e it is) accent.I also love all of Viktors friends especially Eugine Cruz and GUPTA!!! And some of the lines...oh wow, even for a foreigner, Viktor really knows his humor. And I really like the marriage between Eugine and the African-American lady...that was really sweet. The reason I gave the movie a 9 and not a 10 was the constant appearance of Catherine Zeta-Jones. She was good in Ocean's 12, but in this film, I hated her, she really portrayed a slut in some ways. But I really liked the happy ending, the last signature, and everything! Excellent movie!!!

I was ready for a light, cheesy movie; but The Terminal ended up being a total head-scratcher. How can such a stupid plot be made into a high budget movie? The premise itself is ridiculous, and requires a fourth grader's grasp of international relations to accept. Since when does a coup attempt, or a civil war make a country "non-existant".Hanks as Navorski comes across more as a moron than someone who simply doesn't speak English. The love story between Hanks and Zeta-Jones is saved from being a complete cheese-fest at the end by the half-unexpected "twist". The love interest's demise was necessary to bring some semblance of seriousness to the movie after the silly marriage between two secondary characters.

Review title: Premise Is Not Believable / Very Aggravating
Review_body: I can't remember the last time I that a movie was so bad that I couldn't stand to watch the whole thing, now I'll remember.No matter how moronic and sadistic a bureaucracy may be, I just couldn't believe that in the JFK International Terminal that there would be so many people who could blatantly ignore the fact that this poor passenger could understand barely a word they were saying. And I happen to be a Kafka fan, so I've read a little bit about unchecked mindless bureaucracies, and when properly portrayed they're as funny as they are scary; The Terminal was neither.It seemed that the whole airport staff was totally ignorant. Several people kept talking to him in English, even acknowledging that they knew that he couldn't understand what they were saying. They also acknowledged that they needed an interpreter, and even though he was showing them his translation dictionary, and they acknowledged that he had a translation dictionary, no one tried to use it to help the situation.It might have been used as a joke if somebody had suggested that the Stanley Tucci character was an ignoramus, and had him demoted or if someone had filed a lawsuit, or otherwise pointed out the incompetence.But alas I couldn't wait that long. I don't know whether I'm proud or embarrassed that I was able to survive watching 30 min of this totally ridiculous / aggravating / silly waste of time of a movie.I can't believe that Tom Hanks did this movie; I can't believe that it ever got made at all. It's Crap! I give it 1 out of 10, and only for getting me to rent it.

This is a movie that must have seemed good on paper, with all kinds of warm, human messages and morals. They're all there, and quite obvious. Way too obvious. No, this is not a cynical review, it's a disappointed one. The movie's tempo is meandering, the characters are all two-dimensional and clichéd (including Hanks'). There is no satisfying denouement or crescendo -- it's almost a mood piece. While we like Hanks well enough, he comes across as almost a simpleton. His legal limbo and the tension and plot development it brings strains credulity and leaves so many questions unanswered, the work goes from fiction to cartoon.This film in the hands of these artists could have been genius, I'm sure. But it's sophomoric instead. It could be the work of a beginning film class at NYU.

Review title: Why on earth would they make such a crappy movie?
Review_body: In a word, crap. But as they say in the business, the show must go on, and that is what they did. Any movie with such inaccuracies as I will outline should never be able to hit the shelves. Lets see, the first we ever see of our main character we notice that he speaks no English, and when told to go out into the international area, rejected without any access to an lawyer, let alone anyone who speaks his language(which any moron would recognize as at the very least eastern European). I mean come on, first 5 minutes of the movie he has become a non-person who lives in an airport. Now I know it is fiction but come on, even illegal aliens have a right to legal advice when entering the US. not wanting to give away much more of the ever worsening story, why the hell is there a love story? what does his crush have to do with anything in the story what so ever, nothing, it advances the plot none, and just acts as a pain extender to lengthen the movie to make it at least worth the film it was projected from. All in all, EXTREMELY DISAPPOINTED with this movie, and although I usually enjoy Tom Hanks, WHY WOULD HE DERADE HIMSELF TO THIS FILTH!!!! Probably the best part of the movie is that parts of it were filmed in Mirabel Airport, miles away from doing harm to anyone

I have to say it is a great one that first shows the meaning and beauty in our life about waiting and promise. Amelia is waiting for her dream to come true for eighteen years, for herself; Navorski's dad was waiting for something he honored so much for his life; and here comes Navorski, who waits for making his father's left dream come true, for fulfilling his promise, for the woman he fell in love, in a "crack" between the US and his own country. He has done everything for others around him. If there is a great example of "egoless", he is one. Letting go ego, is the greatness that even Amelia found out when she gives up and scarifies something most important in her life to help Navorski. This simple story conveys some wonderful philosophy for people living in this country busy around everyday for business, families, and so on, to slow down and reflect on something. As the retired officer said to officer Dixon, there is something we can learn from Navorski.

My wife and I could only stomach about 20 minutes of this film. I didn't know Steven Spielberg directed this movie until I looked it up on IMDb. I never would have guessed with his instincts he would produce such a frustratingly ham-fisted clichéd film. Being beat over the head with the pretext of the film is not my idea of entertainment. The immigration authorities finally figure out after way too long that the gentleman played by Tom Hanks doesn't understand English. Yet they continue to lecture him in English about immigration law. Huh? I don't get it. The film continues along the same vein. There isn't a sole in the airport that can see he needs some help and doesn't speak the language. Not realistic and plain dumb. We hit "stop" after 20 minutes and kissed our five dollars goodbye.

Once again Tom Hanks shows his range of acting ability! This movie is one of the best I've seen! It made me feel sad and lost on one level, and triumphant on another level as I empathized with his character's predicament. Here is a man willing to live in an airport terminal for an undetermined length or time just to fulfill a promise! Enduring almost-persecution and low-level harassment yet still able to find good things and productive ways to spend his time while he waits.The supporting actors were just as awesome. Stephen Spielberg did an awesome job of directing this film! It's funny, sad, emotional...and very thought-provoking. Has unexpected twists and a satisfying ending.I'm recommending this film to EVERYBODY! Even if you're not a fan of actor(s) or director of this film, it's well worth your time to watch it!

Is this movie really made by the same director that gave us Shindler's List, Jaws and Close Encounters?? What happened to you Steve? Catch Me If You Can wasn't all that good, but this is even worse.The story in a nutshell: A man from a fictitious country lands on JFK airport (presumably with his private jet, since he's the only one coming from this country) but can't enter the USA because his country's government was erased while he was in the air. So all he can do now is wait and hang around the airport.This could have resulted in an interesting movie but it's totally ruined by a number of things:-The cliché image of everybody coming from Eastern Europe being dumb and clumsy-Tom Hanks delivering one the worst fake accents in Hollywood history (do you know the video game "Red Alert"? Well, worse then that)-This is Hollywood so it needs a Romance and a Villain, but neither of them works. I mean, would someone looking like Catherine Zeta Jones really fall for a guy who speaks like that dresses like your math teacher? There is absolutely no chemistry between those two. And this guy Dixon, does he have nothing better to do then bully this poor man?This movie has just too many stereotype characters and movie clichés along with a very VERY unlikely plot which is also full of holes. I just hope that Spielberg regains his old level of movie making again soon.

Review title: Nice Concept, but Wears Out Its Welcome
Review_body: This film does have appeal. I found it to be light-hearted fun along with another Spielberg film that had a similar tone (Catch Me if You Can). Of course, Hanks is masterful, Zeta-Jones is beautiful and Tucci is incredible in his role as a customs agent. I think most viewers will like or liked the cat and mouse banter between Hanks and Tucci's characters. It reminded me a little of how Forrest Gump kept beating the odds stacked against him.Unfortnately, half way through this film you begin to look at your watch. I kept thinking enough is enough. Please just get to the point. It is far too long for a film of this type and the payoff at the end did not justify the lengthiness of this film. I was hoping for an ending with more substance. It doesn't follow formula when it comes to the quasi-relationship between Zeta-Jones and Hanks which is refreshing, but at the end of the film I felt like saying, "Okay, what was this whole exercise for?" I give it a 5 because it lost me halfway through the film.

This was one wonderful movie and deserves a lot of introspection. It brings out several subtle but powerful messages throughout its course..The "Terminal" that Navorski is stuck in symbolizes the world we live in and the time he spends there symbolizes Life itself.The movie's strongest message is that "Life itself is one long wait amidst its various activities and experiences" and hence "Patience is the virtue of life".Most of us have faced situations where life has reached a dead-end and we feel entangled in the web of problems and miseries of life. This is symbolized by Navorski's predicament at the Terminal. Frustration is not an answer, nor is running away or "escaping" it. The solution is to accept the Reality of the situation and adapt our life accordingly by handling all of life's problems with a sense of duty, by putting in our best efforts and leaving the rest to take its own course. Navorski does exactly this during his stint at the "Terminal".Another important message he brings out is that Humanity and Love are the basis of all life and all of our actions need to be based on these principles.Navorski shows this in ample measure by his compassion for fellow human beings and in the end is ready to sacrifice his goal and his wishes for the well-being of his friends.In short, Navorski exemplifies an ideal human being.

Review title: A concept in search of a story.
Review_body: This is Spielberg at his most cloying. A high concept movie without the script to support it, this movie is one contrived situation after the next. There are a host of side stories which add up to nothing. Like the movie itself, most just kind of peter out. The big "mystery" as to why the Hanks character has come to NY is a real letdown and the ultimate resolution appears off screen. The ONLY reason to watch this movie is for Tom Hanks, who soldiers through with a typical engaging Hanksien performance. Compare this movie to Catch Me If You Can and you will see the difference between a Spielberg movie with a story and one that is all about concept. A major disappointment.

When i saw Terminal, i was very happy and to salute the actor basically to Tom Hanks. And also the Director Steven Spielberg and the writers. Thanks for this movie. I love this movie. And want to watch this more and more. When Amelia is stopped in immigration, Viktor waits for her by the gate. However, she must pass through the gate, which is in the international area where Viktor is allowed, to reach the immigration hall. Amelia should get off the aircraft and come through the gate.One of the stamps that Officer Torres puts on Viktor's form says 17 January 2004. A few days later when Dixon and Thurman discusses the office pool on Viktor leaving, Thurman says he's got "January 3rd." When Frank and Victor are in Frank's office toward the beginning of the movie, Frank mentions a Twilight Zone episode named Terror At 30,000 Feet. The episode is actually named Nightmare At 20,000 Feet

The Terminal is a incribile history of an man, capable of everything for a dream; a dream that is not your, but your dad. The film to express the capacity of the perseverance that habit all of us. With a simple plot, was able to touch and make laugh. Tom Hanks show, on more time, how much is a great actor! ^.^ Katerine Zeta Jones have an little part, but too have a great performance. At the beginning, the story make us to think that is Victor ingenuous, but with the pass of the time be evidence his intelligence and creativity to accept the adversity of the destiny. The film is a opportunity to learn how much the patience can bring good look and good friends. I loved it!and I recommend.

Review title: Its always the films that you think you wont like that you love.
Review_body: The terminal sounded like a dead end film to me. It was the trailer that first put me off the film. However, I did promise myself that I would watch the film when it came on DVD because of hanks and Spielberg's contribution. I loved the "Terminal"; in fact it's probably the only film I've watched twice in the same evening. Based on the true story of the Iranian transient in 1988 "who's still there and was offered 1/4 million dollars by Spielberg- at Charles DE Gaulle airport" this film is set at JFK. What I like about the film was that it revolved around relationships with people working at airport rather than lots of small solo stories or stories with other transients like that in "Castaway". Hanks needs others to find that sweet innocence inside him that makes people love him although not necessarily want to make love too him."will explain later" Much of the narrative and directing is excellent / masterful but in places it borders on the ridiculous. It's as if two directors were making the same film. Egg the slapstick scene of hanks trying to sleep on the chairs did not work for me. Perhaps the most intriguing element was the casting of Catherine Zeta Jones. At first I thought that their was no sexual chemistry between the two but then I realised that she had been cast for that precise reason. The two connect on a spiritual level but not on a sexual level. And this is key to the ending of the film. So it was not hanks but CZJ grey haired lover who you envied.IE the man who gives her "great sex" and then leaves her. I feel it is the ending that spooled the film for me. I would have like to have seen some twist regardless of how unrealistic that would make the two transcend the spiritual relationship."the clinch and night they spend together doesn't count" An alternative ending could have been that Victor becomes a celebrity for staying at the airport has TV companies endorsements and is offered a vast amount of money from a movie company to make his biopic. I do want my happy endings when i pay to see mainstream - and love to watch my art /gangster films over the weekend when i expect death loneliness and espresso.Give me chips with my burgers and french beans with my salmon steak.

There were several reasons about why this movie was awesome. First of all, I get really tired of seeing redundant movies. I want to see a movie every once in awhile with substance like this film had. I have an older daughter, 12, who watched it with me. I didn't have to explain too much to her. She understood how clever Victor (Hank character) had become, once he was approached by the acting Airport Commissioner, and how he was even more empowered when he began to grasp the Englsih language. Another reason it was great is that we got to see the commitment Victor had to his dead father. How many of us wouldn't have bolted for the door. I also appreciated how Mr. Spielberg showed that many times, the "man" is always trying to get us down, and that many times, we can "stick it to him" with intelligence.

um.. nice movie I'm mean i have no time to tell the whole story but u have to see it... tom hanks did a gr8 job he needs a clap and even the other actors were good. The story is something really different and um... i mean the movie was good it has every category: romance, drama and comedy.. a must see... don't know about u people but i rate this movie a "10" and um i guess that i have to do this for 10 lines so.. lets think what Else to write........thinking.......thinking......Huff .........um......okay......so this story is about a guy in airport who lives for 9 months.........thinking.. yes 10 lines got over.. thank people and if u wanna be my friend mail me..( i wrote just because nothing else to write but I'm serious)Rebecca

Review title: One of the best I've seen
Review_body: This movie is easily one of the best I have seen so far . Everybody does their bit pretty well ranging from Tom Hanks to the Indian guy who plays the sweeper. Spielberg has delivered once again and the movie shows why most laws are meant to be broken . And the fact that he does not get Zeta-Jones in the end makes it even more beautiful.The movie starts with Hank's character coming to America and discovering at the airport that his country is no longer recognized by the US ,which makes him a man without a country.He can neither get out nor in to the US and has to stay in the airport till the problems in his country are sorted out.And there is this really interesting character played by Tucci who lives by the law and does everything in his power to force Hanks out . And how this man who does not even know English adapts to everything and manages to make himself comfortable in the most uncomfortable situation makes this one hell of a movie.

Review title: Great "Little Movie" makes waves of emotions.
Review_body: This is a great "Little movie" with more charm than I imagined. This movie portrays foreigner Viktor Navorski(Tom Hanks)trapped inside an airport. He deals with loss of country, language barriers, vindictive authorities, and confinement only inches from his goal for more than nine months. Anyone who has traveled to foreign shores can identify with this man's anxiety. Outstanding performance from Catherine Zeta Jones as believable flight bimbo waiting for Mr. Right and her life to come in for a landing. Some silly scenes exist but the message rings of hope as this man makes his way back from nowhere to achieve his dead Fathers wish. Heartwarming and funny, this movie is well worth your dime.

This was an entertaining movie, but it would have been much nicer to see it directed by someone else, and played by an ACTUAL foreign actor. Much as Tom Hanks does an admirable job, it just irritates me to see Americans put on a generic "foreign" accent and walk funny, act funny, and just generally play an irritating twit and think that's what it means to be 'foreign'. It might go down well with the troops in Alabama, but in the rest of the world it's just offensive and to me it goes to the root of why America has a serious image problem in the world today. Where is it written that if you are from "Krakosia" that you immediately take on some kind of a strange, "old man" gait like Hanks does in the film. Does he have hemorrhoids? Is he knocked-kneed? And whether it's Spielberg or the writers who are responsible, the 'Commissioner' in this film is like a cartoon character. How or why could he possibly HATE Viktor so much? Not to mention all the secondary characters are like characters from Children's movies. There were moments (such as when Gupta, the Indian Janitor is telling Viktor's heroic tale) when I felt like I was watching the Goonies or ET again. I enjoyed this film, but I probably will go check out the French version now, just because it is -irritating- when big American studios cast big American actors to play a very small, foreign character. For a foreigner, in this film Hanks' character has a remarkably American sense of humor. Once again Spielberg falls just short of biting satire and descends into sentimental tripe.

Overall I thought the movie was very enjoyable, but I couldn't quite decide which accent Hanks wanted to use. If you listen closely, you can notice that his accent is different from scene to scene and at times it made it difficult to follow what he was saying. I watched the movie on TV, maybe the sound was better at the theater. Did anyone else notice this who saw the movie or was it just my ears playing tricks on me, well I am getting up there in the ages, perhaps it is time for me to think about a hearing aid. I thought the plot was a little lacking, was it a love story or was it about immigration? I thought that the ending could have been better - like Hanks ends up the stewardess, but that is a typical Hanks movie ending. They never really end the way you want them too. I think I have blabbed on now for the 10 lines of text minimum rule. :)

It was a pleasant surprise for me  Tom Hanks speaking in my native Bulgarian language (and it is not Russian). His performance was outstanding, I could have sworn he was a relative to my father-in-law  gestures, posture, skills, desire to do the right thing and a heart of gold.This gentle comedy portrays Eastern Europeans in a much more sympathetic and realistic way than everything else I've seen in the West, and shows the West in ways that many migrants have experienced. It is entertaining and charmingly stupid at places, as real life. It also has this warm feel of optimism, simplicity and satisfaction that our consumerist society has almost made extinct.Thanks to Spillberg for this beautiful movie which made my day.

This is one of the worst movies I've ever seen. Stupid story lines and dialogue and acting so cringe-worthy that I had to fast-forward a lot of the film. What a shame as it's a interesting idea but handled really badly. I look forward to the Hanks and Spielberg combination normally as at least you know you'll be entertained. But not this time. And Catherine Zeta-Jones...possibly the least sympathetic role she's ever played. I'm not sure that was all down to the character as well. The one highlight of this film and unfortunately he is not in every seen is the runaway Indian man who works in the terminal as a cleaner. I don't know who the actor was but his part in this saved me form ejecting the video altogether.
Was average until the woman declining his daily applications drove the airport with her new husband. The rooftop dining area was also hilarious.
Best comedy. i loved it. great acting by tom hanks

Review title: Splendid Hanks makes it a memorable film
Review_body: Any one who has spent some time on airport can find a number of relatable characters and incidents in the movie. One of the finest performance by Tom Hanks. He is the real star of the film. My rating 9 is solely based on how Hanks has managed to single-handedly engaged the audience throughout. Some other side characters have put in a commendable performance. There are moments in the movie that makes it a memorable watch. The romantic element in the movie spoils the fun, for me. Unrealistic ending makes it look like a Bollywood masala movie (which has a lot of emotion without making much (or any) sense). Despite of that I consider it to be a must-watch. It can still do a lot of business in flights and airports as the emotional state of the audience would be much more active. Hanks, alone, deserve a 10 star rating.

Just when you think you've seen Tom Hanks at his best, he gives another sensational performance and surprises you! This movie proves that he is a versatile and truly entertaining performer. The way he mastered the accent was fantastic! The other characters only added to the charm and humor of the movie. I absolutely loved the character of Gupta. Also, the romance between the food delivery guy and the immigration lady was real sweet. The movie unravels in a most interesting manner, which also proves to be highly engrossing. I was amazed by how the story didn't become monotonous after a while, and remained very, VERY enjoyable.Good stuff!

There was nothing really in the video store, so we thought we'd get the Terminal since it was about the only somewhat new release that was in.I really wish I had my money back and the 25 minutes that I invested into this film. Yes, I really only made it 25 minutes into the movie until I practically ran to the DVD player to eject it.There was not one thing funny or even remotely entertaining within the first 25 minutes. It was so ridiculous to watch supposed airport personnel continue to have lengthy and in depth conversations with someone that doesn't even understand English. Do yourself a favor, if you're in the same situation I was, go and rent an oldie but a goody.

Review title: This movie is about a guy that loses his country and then get stuck in-between the U.S and "nothing". Therefore he has to stay a long period in a airport.
Review_body: When Viktor (Tom Hanks) is traveling to the U.S to fulfill a dream his father had before he died. Viktors country got in a war and by that Viktor's passport isn't legit anymore. In this movie the airport doesn't have any way to help him. He cant go home to his country because it technically "doesn't exist" and he cant go to the U.S because his passport isn't legit. So then, the boss at the airport decides to let him stay there until further investigation. The movie is about a man who is really nice to everyone. And at the end his way to live gives us a good movie with a heartbreaking story. It is a drama-comedy though, so there is also many funny and weird moments. I first watched this movie as a child, at the time I didn't understand the story at all. The same year I was watching movies without any plot, so this movie was something else at the time. Now when I am older, this movie easily got to my top list of movies. It is maybe one of the ten best movies I have watched.This is a must watch movie. There was something about this movie, even though I didn't understand it at first. I did see something that brought me back years later to watch it as an adult. Also this movie has gotten a lot of good critics all over the world. Just a week ago this movie was aired on a TV-channel here in Norway. 11 years after its release."The Terminal" is really a movie to watch. If it isn't on your "to watch list" or "have watched list" then add it in! You wont regret it.

I watched this film for the second time last night, as I recently saw Spielberg's latest, War of the Worlds, and was in a Spielberg mood! What I like about the Terminal is that it, for me, has a lot of similarities to the old Billy Wilder films such as The Apartment and Irma La Douce, in that love/romance springs up in the most unlikely of places or situations. It is great to see modern filmmakers returning to the roots of film-making in this way! There are plenty of humorous elements in this, and the characters are interesting and the storytelling rich. Tom Hanks plays Viktors character very convincingly, and the three friends he meets in the terminal are convincingly portrayed. Nice one!
This movie for me is a top 5 Tom hanks movie i love comedy drama romance !

This movie is terribly boring. The cutting is very bad with obvious mistakes. Actors performance does not worth to mention, Hanks accent was the best part of it... but you don't need to make a movie for that...*****SPOILER***** Many junk scene - like when the workers at the terminal clap their hands for Hanks making a big applause. When the good old Indian guy stops the airplane, when the SWAT(or what) aims their gun at him. *****SPOILER*****Many many scenes made me to cry out (not) in (physical) pain.So all in all this is a JUNK MOVIEbut i still like Hanks and Spielberg...

Review title: You People Are A Piece Of Work
Review_body: I see people on here saying this movie is based on a true story or loosely based on a true story... HORSE*Crap* this is a quote taken directly from the terminal movie website..."That idea grew into the screenplay 'The Terminal', which told the story of Viktor Navorski, an entirely fictional character from the equally fictitious Eastern European country of Krakozhia, who is en route to New York City when his country is torn apart by war. Review title: Enjoyable film yet something was missing
Review_body: I found the movie to be enjoyable, yet there were a number of misses that could have elevated the film to greatness.First, nothing came of the relationship between Hank's character and Jones'. Second, it seemed Tucchi's character kept vacillating between liking him and dismissing him. Third, the ending was not good. Everything for just an autograph? How about something else like someone who saved his father's life during a war or someone who wronged his father or someone who was his own father. I mean of all the emotional surprises, this had to be at the bottom.Nevertheless, the film was good.
This one started out well but really went off the rails at the end. The last half hour was like some wacky slapstick comedy.

Review title: The movie is about a man who upon arriving in the United States becomes stateless because his nation has fallen in a coup.
Review_body: The idea of filming an entire film at an airport, the simplicity of the protagonist superbly played by Tom Hanks and the brilliant direction by Steven Spielberg makes The Terminal one of the finest movies made so far. The Terminal is a lightweight movie. It doesn't get into any deep discussion on the human condition but it still manages to show how love can break the barriers of language and regionalism to bond people so strongly. The cast is great and all of them have delivered commendable performances. The writing offers enough laughter and some touching moments. One negative aspect of the film is the littering of product advertisements in nearly every scene. To sum up, Spielberg, his actors and writers have woven the movie into a crowd-pleasing and entertaining film about humanity and heart, that creates sympathy for all its characters through its entire flow and leaves the viewer unreasonably happy at the end. I will rate this movie 9/10 and will highly recommend it to those who haven't watched it yet.

This is a great film, the comedy, the romance are simply perfect takes you away from depressions and everyday life. The European accent and histrionic of Tom Hanks are simply fantastic. Steven Spielberg narrated it the way where you wouldn't get bored or anything. I still can't figure out why people wrote bad reviews about it. I agree that the movie gets a little unrealistic in climax and certain situations, but that wouldn't matter because there are Scifi movies like alien and other fantasy movies and they are all unrealistic. Thanks to the Legendary filmmaker "Steven Spielberg" and the best of the best "Tom Hanks" for giving such wonderful entertainment.

I've watched more than 1000 movies which every one of them have a message. I'd liked or disliked their message. Terminal had a simple message, Fight problems, love each other. Perhaps this movie has a simple story that you can predict the whole story but Tom Hanks shows us how his act and his accent makes Terminal a VALUABLE movie that you don't regret for your time and money spent. This movie shows you loving each other doesn't need any Language. You just need to show your feeling, the others will understand that. It doesn't matter what nationality or race you are, when one is in trouble, we had to help. Helping others is helping ourselves. Steven Spielberg shows us another masterpiece with simple story.

I loved the movie. It had story, acting, humour, romance, drama. It's a complete package.
It's an inspirational movie- how a tourist manages to live and turn tough time into good time, at airport without violating any law.
Never give up and never lose yourself in hard time.

Just One word to describe movie . awesome and Must Watch. Best Movie ever. Tom Hanks acts effortlessly and you are going to fell in love with him. All characters has played their part exceptionally well. Simple yet powerful. Each scene in movie is so loving. So do watch this movie and enjoy.

This movie tells a story of a man (Viktor Navorski) that leaves Krakozhia but during the flight his country suffers a Revolution and when he arrives to USA, his passaport and ID are not accepted by the USA government.
Like the majority of Steven Spielberg movies, this movie attracts who is watching it since the beginning, with an excellent performance of Tom Hanks as always.
A must see film for all Spielberg fans for sure!
Viktor Navorski (Tom Hanks) will pass almost a year in the airport, get a job, will fall in love for a woman that works in a Airline Company, build his own room, show his work skills and get a new family in the airport, basically, he gained a new family there.
A drama, romance and comedy film for all ages, an excellent film to see with family in a Sunday evening!
Simply one of the best motion pictures ever made, I was expecting the rating to be at least 9/10, I'm really surprised. Watched it twice and wouldn't mind watch it more times

Review title: heart touching on immigrants' point of view
Review_body: This is a very nice piece of work by Steven Spielberg. I thought of this movie as being based on a true story of a man trapped at an airport for 2 years as i was watching the film. As an once non-English speaking immigrant who stepped into the foreign airport myself, I found the story very compelling and touching. Tom Hank's actions were terrific, although if there were some drawbacks it was hard to figure out a relative time frame, when and how long things have been happening for in the film.I actually found the catch phrase "Do you have an appointment" quite funny, it would've been strange for non-English speaking non-migrants as the whole movie may not make sense. But everyones been to airports, and facing language barrier is one of the biggest discomforts. Waiting at a airport even for an hour or two seems terrible, but if that goes on for months even years what would it be like? The movie has answered that, as well as giving me an insight into Mr Navoski's airport life very well. Tom Hanks is a wonderful actor.

Did you know, that the main character actually speaks in Bulgarian?Yes, I myself was a bit surprised :) As far as I know, the country, Crakonia, or something like that, is not real, but Bulgaria is :) The pronunciation is quite understandable, excluding the part where he talks to the "Russian guy". I really loved the way "our man" saved the poor man's father, but I did not figure how the Russian understood the idea, may be he actually spoke a bit English and understood the story of "our man".Anyway, I really enjoyed the movie. I also cried here and there as I was touched by some moments... but I recommend you find your own moments :)

First, I want to apologize for my bad English. So don't criticize me or disturb yourself by my English. I thank you very much. The reason that I write this comment, although my English isn't perfect, is the fact that "The Terminal" is really one of the best movies that there is.The movie begins in the Terminal, when Viktor Navorski (Tom Hanks) got picked up by the security. The reason is the fact that his country, Krakozhia, is in the progress of a revolution. This makes the passport of Viktor invalid. Not knowing what is happening, he says many times "I go New York". With some funny scenes he gets to know what is happening. After this there comes a long time of living in the airport.The director of the airport wants that he'll get out of this airport, but he can't do this without that Viktor makes a foul. Viktor does a lot of things in the airport, and makes himself home. After some times he makes friends, the progress in making these friend were always funny, but also dramatic, as one of the audience I felt very combined to him. He gets to know a woman, Amelia Jane Warren (Catherina Zeta-Jones) They become friends and maybe even.. With Amelia in the story, the story gets the factor love. Combined with the funny and dramatic part, it makes the story almost perfect. I must praise the scriptwriter; it really is a piece of masterwork.The actors, with Tom Hanks, Catherina Zeta-Jones and Stanley Tucci played really good in the movie. There wasn't any kind of hesitation or sign of unreality. I must praise even more about the actor skills of Tom Hanks, although he knows the English language better than me, he was able to make me believe that my skills in English were far more better than his. This is really astonishing.The music in the story also was very good and fitted very best in the movie. I can't have complaints about that.The ending of the story is..how should I say it.."perfect with some hesitations". The first thing with the ending is that you'll see what kind of genius the scriptwriter is. It has a lot of symbolic thing, what makes watching the movie twice very attractive. The second thing is a personal thing..you'll collide it.In the end I want to tell you something about the making of the scenes, the audience will get the feeling that he is right now in the screen, in the airport. This is a really good achievement, for the director, Steven Spielberg.With the really perfect script (if there was an even stronger praise word I would use that) very skill full actors and good scenes. I give this movie a nine. I must warn you that, if you don't like comedy, love and drama, you must not watch this movie. But if you like one of these factors, I recommend you this movie. If you like two of these factors you must see it! And if you like all three of them..you'll have the time of your live, on my word.Cario Dally
